metadata.title: Finger Flexor Tendon  Surgical Repair
anatomical location body part affected: Flexor digitorum superficialis and/or flexor digitorum profundus; depending on the initial injury, surrounding digital nerves and blood vessels, bone, ligaments, and other soft tissue may also be damaged
description: The flexor tendonsystemis divided into zones and injuries are characterized by the zone in which they occur:(14) –Zone 1: Base of the distal phalanx to the middle of the middle phalanx; distal to the insertion of the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) –Zone 2: Middle phalanx to the distal palmar crease (i.e., A1 pulley); fibro-osseous tunnel –Zone 3: Palm; distal palmar crease to the distal edge of the transverse ligament (i.e., carpal tunnel) –Zone 4: Carpal tunnel; underlies the transverse carpal ligament –Zone 5: Carpal tunnel to forearm; extends proximally from the proximal edge of the carpal ligament to the musculotendinous juncture of the long flexor tendons

Types of surgical repair (based on etiology of the injury, location of the injury, and patient’s presentation)(1) –Immediate primary repair – occurs within 24 hours (post injury) –Delayed primary repair – occurs within 10 days (post injury); utilized if infection is likely –Secondary repair – occurs within 10 days to 3 weeks (post injury); utilized if numerous injuries to the hand have occurred –Late reconstruction – occurs within months (post injury); utilized if numerous injuries to the hand have occurred or with late presentation (e.g., athlete waiting until the end of the season) –Staged reconstruction – occurs over a protracted time frame and involves more than one surgery to the hand; utilized if numerous injuries to the hand have occurred or with failure of primary repair or if primary repair cannot be performed

Individuals participating in occupational or leisure activities requiring the use of machines, tools, or other sharp and potentially hazardous equipment and individuals participating in contact sports are at increased risk for finger tendon injury. Persons with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are at increased risk for a traumatic flexor tendon injury
indications: The mechanism of injury is usually a puncture, laceration, or other open injury to the hand or finger, resulting in complete or partial severing of one or more of the tendons within the digit, hand, or wrist

Sports accidents may also cause rupture of the finger flexor tendons, especially if the finger is pulled or stretched (e.g., jersey finger, an avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus [FDP] tendon from the distal phalanx)
Spontaneous rupture secondary to RA may also cause finger flexor tendon ruptures

Once the tendon has been lacerated or ruptured, the proximal end often begins to retract and, rarely, the distal end, making surgical repair more difficult if the patient is not operated on within a few days of injury. Additionally, adhesions, scarring, and contractures may begin to develop secondary to the loss of ability to actively move the affected digit(s). Repair within the first 12–48  hours is ideal

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Complete laceration or rupture of flexor tendon(s) of the hand generally requires surgical management as retraction of the flexor tendons is common(1) and the tendons will not heal without repair

Patient will present postoperatively with sutures and sterile dressing in place. The patient may present from the operating room in a half-cast  or other temporary immobilization apparatus. Depending on the number of days since surgery, the wound may be draining serosanguineous fluid. Significant edema often is present in the affected digit, as well as in the other digits and the hand Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications

overall contraindications precautions: Patients status post finger flexor tendon repair should wear a customized immobilization orthosis at all times following surgery, usually for about 4 weeks
There should be no full composite wrist and digit extension (to avoid excessive stress on the repaired tendons)
There should be no active flexion of the finger(s) unless directed by the surgeon

There should be no lifting with the affected hand (until permitted by surgeon) Approach and progression of therapy should be patient-centered  and involve input from the surgeon, therapist, and patient(2,28)

Carefully inspect the surgical incision for presence of infection. If infection is suspected (e.g., redness, odor, warmth, increased pain, purulent drainage, general malaise), the patient should be referred back to the hand surgeon immediately for further evaluation and treatment

The therapist should follow the protocol established by his or her clinic and by the hand surgeon regarding active and PROM limitations. The priority in the first stages postoperatively is protection of the tendon repair. If flexor lag is observed following flexor tendon repair, or if the patient reports or the therapist witnesses an audible or palpable “pop,” the patient should be referred back to the hand surgeon immediately to evaluate the possibility of re-rupture  of the repaired tendon
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients usually present to therapy within the first 24 to 48 hours postoperatively. They may require fabrication of a postoperative orthosis. The surgical incision will have sutures and a sterile dressing in place. The mechanism of injury may have been an open wound, athletic injury, or spontaneous rupture

course of treatment.medical management: Surgery is performed via one of two methods(1) Direct repair  the separated portions of the tendon are reconnected There is some variability in the type of repair performed. The authors of a study conducted in the United States found that the majority of hand surgeons (65.3%) responding to a survey about zone 2 repairs perform a 4strand  repair using 30 or 4-0 braided, nonabsorbable suture material along with an epitendinous repair. Four hundred ten surgeons responded to the survey. Of those who responded, surgeons with ≥ 15 years in practice were more likely to use a 2strand  repair and passive (vs. early active) rehabilitation protocol(23) Authors of a basic science study propose new repair techniques (asymmetric and circumferential) that utilize FDS autograft to buttress repairs instead of a core suture. Based on a cadaveric sheep study, the authors demonstrated tensile strength similar to 6strand  repairs and greater than 2- and 4-strand  repairs. In addition, the asymmetric repair required greater force than the 6strand  repair to create a 2 mm gap(30) Reconstruction/tendon graft  this method is utilized when pronounced tension on the tendon would prohibit a direct repair Investigation continues into the factors involved in tendon healing and adhesion formation. A better understanding of the role of gene expression in tendon development may help to identify factors that can be utilized (e.g., growth factors, cytokines, chemokines) to facilitate healing and prevent adhesions(15) Use of “wide-awake”  surgery, in which the repair is done with local anesthesia and without tourniquet, is an emerging technique that allows assessment of ROM and quality of repair (and corrections to be made as needed) before incision closure(23,24,29) The shift toward early active motion after flexor tendon repair in order to prevent complications has evolved because of surgical techniques that provide a stronger repair(3,14,18)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  X-ray  or MRI may be required to rule out fracture, presence of foreign body, or other abnormality
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients may have significant postoperative pain, and may also have significant pain with PROM during physical therapy sessions
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, flexor lag, audible pop)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise present? (Need for supplemental oxygen, cough, etc.) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes _ No _ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Patients with RA may have experienced prior spontaneous tendon ruptures related to their condition
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Does the patient have RA or any other condition that may result in a predisposition to tendon rupture? Are there any other injuries related to the tendon rupture (nerve injury/repair, fracture, etc.)? Smokers and patients with diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for poor healing. Any other significant medical history?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What is the patient’s occupation? Can it be done single-handedly?  Return to work will depend on the nature of the job; light hand use (e.g., using a keyboard or pen) can be resumed sooner than heavier activities (e.g., lifting, driving, building). Does the patient need to drive to get to work? Does the patient work with machinery, sharp tools, glass, or animals? Which hand is dominant? Does the patient participate in any sporting activities? Does the patient engage in any other bimanual hand-intensive  activities (e.g., needlework, knitting)?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (e.g., caregivers, family members)? If the patient lives alone, are there individuals available to assist with bimanual tasks? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications (to either environment or tasks) necessary?

Complete a general assessment as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Distal pulses should be normal, but in severe hand traumas digital artery damage may have occurred. Take note of increased pallor, cyanotic color of the finger(s), and coolness of the finger –Allen test can be used to assess circulation/capillary refill(21)There is often significant edema and warmth following surgical tendon repair. Edema may be present in the affected digit and may also be present in the surrounding digits and hand. Circumferential measurements may be taken to monitor the severity of edema; volumetric measurements may be appropriate, once healed and with adherence to

contraindications precautions: Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation or poor circulation, or slow-healing wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
over epiphyseal plates of growing bones
Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits
Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments
Use caution over plastic or metal implants
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinics/hospitals and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Rehabilitation goals are to facilitate differential tendon gliding and influence collagen structure, strengthen the tendon repair, and minimize risk of rupture, adhesion formation, or tendon repair gapping(3)
Therapeutic ultrasound contraindications; do not use:(4)

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(4)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A patient who presents status post finger flexor tendon repair will require wound care, edema control, splinting, and appropriate PROM and AROM, with progression to strengthening and functional retraining
prognosis: Factors that affect prognosis include the type of injury, the surgical technique employed, the skill of the surgeon, the patient’s characteristics, associated injuries, and the rehabilitation program used(14,27)

Authors of retrospective case series of patients < 6 years old treated for flexor tendon injury in the United States found that in their series of 12 digits in 10 patients, good outcomes were seen at an average of 8 years post repair (range: 2 to 19 years) in both primary repair and 2-stage  reconstructions, although better results were obtained with primary repair(26)
Injuries in zone 2 are the most difficult to treat(6) and may have worse outcomes than injuries in other zones

Prognostic factors for outcomes of surgically repaired tendon(14) –Patient demographics: age, comorbidities, health habits (e.g., smoking has negative impact) –Psychosocial factors: patient motivation and willingness to be compliant with the postoperative protocol –Socioeconomic barriers: may impact compliance and ability to attend therapy
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Certified hand therapist (occupational therapist [OT] or physical therapist [PT]) as indicated Physician or referring surgeon for infection, wound healing concerns
treatment summary: In the acute stage, the goals are to protect the repair, prevent tendon adherence, and control edema. In the subacute stage, the goal is to increase ROM. In the later stages, increasing strength and improving hand function are the primary goals(5,6)

Many different protocols exist regarding the progression following flexor tendon repair; surgeons and hand therapists commonly modify and combine the protocols in practice to best meet the demands of the specific clinical scenario(5,6)

The three most common evidence-supported  flexor tendon protocols are immobilization, early passive motion, and early active mobilization. The approach used will vary depending on zone of injury.(2) Patient characteristics and nature of repair will also influence rehabilitation decisions(30) –Active mobilization protocols are associated with larger tendon excursions than passive mobilization protocols, thus reducing adhesion formation; however, excessive stress can increase risk of rupture(7) –Immobilization technique is another protocol, and is most often used with noncompliant patients or young children(32) -The affected hand is immobilized in a cast for 3–4weeks following surgery and then substituted with a dorsal blocking splint for 2 more weeks -The dorsal blocking splint is discharged at 4–6weeks -At 3–4 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts passive digital flexion and extension exercises and active tendon gliding exercises -At 4–6 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts gentle blocking exercises -At 6–8 weeks, the patient starts gentle resistive exercises -This technique is associated with tendon ruptures but is favored with children, noncompliant or impulsive patients, and patients with extensive hand injuries or impaired cognition(1) -Immobilization now tends to be used only with patients who are too young or lack cognitive ability to understand precautions of an early mobilization protocol or if associated injuries such as fractures contraindicate mobilization(2) –Early passive motion (early controlled motion protocols)(2,6) -Since early controlled motion following tendon repair was first proposed, research has provided significant clinical evidence to support its use(8,9,10,11,12) -Most early passive mobilization protocols follow an early (0–3 weeks), intermediate (3–6 weeks), and late (6–8 weeks and beyond) stage timeline(2) -The early stage coincides with the inflammatory stage of healing. A dorsal block hand and wrist orthosis (wrist position between 20° flexion to 20° extension and MCP 40-50°  flexion) typically is used to limit movement -In the earlystage, passive flexion is provided manually or via rubber band traction (see Kleinert technique, below) -In the intermediate stage, active flexion exercises may be initiated while continuing the use of the dorsal block splint -Most protocols discontinue the splint at 6 weeks and allow initiation of gentle resistive exercise (6 to 8 weeks);however, this typically is determined by the surgeon  -Louisville (or Kleinert) technique allows for protected tendon gliding to reduce scar adherence but may cause PIP joint contractures -The patient wears a splint that holds the wrist and MCP joints in flexion (40° and 45°, respectively) for 24 hours a day for 3 weeks -Rubber bands are attached on one end to the fingernails (using glue) and on the other end to the splint so that the PIP joints are in 40–60°  of flexion -The patient actively extends the interphalangeal joints several times a day and allows the bands to pull the fingers back into the flexed position -If the patient has PIP joint contractures, dynamic extension splinting can begin at 5–6 weeks postoperatively -At 6 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts blocking exercises -At 6–8 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts gentle resistive exercises -Modified Kleinert splinting may be used to perform hourly exercises by the patient. The rubber band/pulley portion of the splint is used to passively flex the digits, and the patient is able to actively extend the digits. When the patient ceases extending, the tension of the rubber band on the splint passively returns the finger to a flexed position. The patient may perform 10 repetitions per hour. The patient should be cautioned not to actively flex the digits(2,8) -Modified Duran and Houser technique(6) -The patient starts passive flexion and extension exercises (twice per day) on the third postoperative day while the wrist is flexed and the MP joints are flexed to 70° -At approximately 5 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts blocking exercises -At approximately 7 weeks postoperatively, the patient starts gentle resistive exercises –Early active motion protocol(6) -Patients begin active tendon gliding within the first 48 hours post repair in a controlled and protected manner(2) -This protocol is appropriate only for specific suture strand repairs due to high rates of tendon rupture if utilized with other types of repairs(6,11) -Results of a biomechanical study designed to assess the strength of common core suture repairs indicate that braided cruciate repairs provided strength similar to 6- and 8-strand repairs(18) -Most active mobilization protocols incorporate a tenodesis orthosisthat is applied 3 to 5 days post-surgery  which limits wrist and MCP extension but allows digit flexion using tenodesis. At 7–14 days after surgery place-hold  exercises are initiated and at 14 to 21 days AAROM using buddy strapping is started. The program is progressed to AROM at 28 days after surgery and full active wrist and digit extension at 35 days. Use of the orthosis is discontinued at 7 to 9 weeks after repair(2) -The particular progression of the protocol depends on the surgeon -The type and amount of active mobilization varies with each protocol.All limit active tendon gliding during weeks 1–3(2)

An ultrasonographic study of flexor tendon excursions in different mobilization protocols was conducted in the Netherlands to assess the effect of the position of adjacent fingers on long finger FDP tendon excursion(7) –Studies have indicated that the surrounding tissue moves in the same direction as the tendon, so that tendon movement relative to the surrounding tissue may be smaller than absolute tendon movement –Hence, it may be misleading to study tendon excursions measured with respect to a nonmoving reference such as a ruler or a bone –The investigators hypothesized that the positions of adjacent fingers influence the long finger FDP excursion –Using frame-to-frame  analysis of ultrasound images, long finger FDP tendon excursions and surrounding tissue movement were measured in 11 healthy subjects during 3 different rehabilitation protocols and 2 experimental protocols -Active 4-finger  mobilization protocol -Passive 4-finger  mobilization protocol -Modified Kleinert mobilization protocol -Experimental model based on modified Kleinert but with adjacent fingers in full flexion -Experimental model based on modified Kleinert but with adjacent fingers in full extension –Large and significant differences among the different rehabilitation protocols and experimental models were observed in absolute and relative tendon displacement –The positions of the adjacent fingers during tendon mobilization protocols have a large influence on tendon excursions  –It was concluded that the most commonly used protocols may not lead to optimal tendon excursions and that clinicians should also focus on adjacent fingers during rehabilitation after tendon repair

Authors of a systematic review designed to identify the optimal postoperative rehabilitation program found insufficient evidence to support true active motion regimens as superior to other motion approaches(33) . maintenance or prevention: Patients should be compliant with splint/orthosis use and home exercise program to protect the integrity of the repair and produce an optimal recovery. Individuals at risk for tendon injuries should adhere to all safety policies and regulations and use appropriate safety equipment when working with machines, tools, glass, and animals
